Award.AwardTitle: Nonlinear Flow and Flight Tracking Control Methods for Unmanned Aerial Vehicles Using Microjet Actuators

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The primary science objective of this award is to develop new methods of simultaneous flow and flight control for microjet actuator-based unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs) in the presence of uncertain operating conditions and uncertain nonlinear actuator dynamics. Microjet actuators transfer linear momentum to a flow system by using a vibrating diaphragm, which creates trains of vortices through the alternating ejection and suction of fluid through a small orifice. Microjets can be utilized to modify the boundary layer flow field near the surface of an aircraft wing, which can improve UAV aerodynamic performance and maneuverability. Benefits of the use of microjet actuators include small size, ease of operation, low cost, and no requirement for a separate fuel supply. The study will investigate new methods of nonlinear control, which incorporate the complete nonlinear UAV dynamics in addition to the boundary-layer flow field dynamics in the design. A focus of the proposed research will be the development of practical control designs that require minimal computational complexity. Deliverables include new theoretical control design techniques, demonstrations via numerical simulations, performance validation via wind-tunnel experiments, engineering student education and research experiences, and hands-on student projects.

It is expected that the results of this research will reduce implementation cost and improve performance of UAV control systems. Moreover, the research will create practical microjet-based control methods that can be applied over a wide range of operating conditions. This will enable the development of cost-effective UAV systems that are capable for real-life implementation. The result of the research will be document in research papers that will be disseminated in conference proceedings and high-impact academic journals. Graduate and undergraduate students will benefit through involvement in research and hands-on projects, which they will draw on throughout their academic or industrial careers.

POR.DRECONTENT:
New theoretical control design methods were developed and validated in this research project, which are proven to achieve reliable and accurate control for small unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs) using synthetic jet actuators (SJAs) as opposed to mechanical deflection surfaces (e.g., ailerons or elevators). SJAs are promising tools for small UAV control applications by virtue of their small size, low cost, low power requirement, and ease of operation.

SJAs transfer linear momentum to a flow system by using a vibrating diaphragm, which creates trains of vortices through the alternating ejection and suction of fluid through a small orifice (see enclosed diagram). Since these vortices (i.e., jets) are formed entirely from the fluid (i.e., air) of the flow system, a key benefit of SJAs is that they achieve this transfer of momentum with zero net mass injection across the flow boundary. Thus, SJAs do not require space for a fuel supply. SJAs can be utilized to modify the boundary layer flow field near the surface of an UAV wing, which can improve aerodynamic performance. Moreover, arrays consisting of several SJAs can be employed to achieve maneuvering control of UAVs, possibly eliminating the need for mechanical control surfaces.

Specific challenges addressed in this project include new, practically implementable control methods to compensate for the parametric uncertainty and nonlinearity inherent in the mathematical model describing the SJA control force. Eschewing computationally cumbersome control methods that employ time-varying parameter identification algorithms or computational intelligence (e.g., neural networks) to compensate for the SJA model uncertainty, the newly developed control methods employ constant feedforward “best guess” estimates of the uncertain SJA parameters. By leveraging advantageous mathematical properties in the control law derivations, the resulting control systems are shown to completely compensate for the SJA uncertainty using computationally simplistic control strategies using the constant estimates.

The control applications addressed in the research project include 1) UAV trajectory tracking control; 2) Limit cycle oscillation (LCO) (or wing vibration) suppression; and 3) Fluid flow velocity regulation. The specific outcomes of the research project in flight tracking control include zero steady-state error UAV trajectory tracking control in the presence of external wind gusts, UAV model uncertainty, and SJA actuator model uncertainty. The specific outcomes for the LCO suppression control objective include 1) A new method of SJA-based LCO control using an output feedback control method, which eliminates the need for noisy and inaccurate sensor measurements of LCO velocity and 2) The first robust nonlinear control design to rigorously prove zero steady-state error LCO regulation for so-called dual-parallel underactuated systems, where a single control signal is simultaneously coupled to both the pitching (twisting motion) and plunging (vertical motion) LCO states. The specific outcomes for the fluid flow control objective include the first SJA-based flow field velocity control method, which is rigorously proven to achieve zero steady-state error velocity regulation for a fluid flow field using only direct sensor measurements of the flow field velocity.

Practically speaking, a primary contribution of this research project is a one-size-fits-all automatic control design approach for SJA-based UAVs, which is mathematically proven to achieve reliable and accurate trajectory tracking control and LCO suppression for small UAVs in the presence of realistic, unpredictable operating conditions and uncertain SJA actuator dynamics. Moreover, the control methods developed in this research are designed to be computationally inexpensive, such that they are practical in applications involving small UAVs, where onboard space and computational power are limited.

Beyond the contributions to fundamental controls research, there are significant educational and industrial ramifications resulting from this research project. Specifically, the broader impacts of this project include 1) The foundation for the PhD dissertation research for two students at the principle investigator’s (PI’s) home institution; 2) Several peer-reviewed publications in international science conferences and upper-tier science journals, including multiple international presentations of new control-theoretic research results; 3) Hands-on experience with computer simulation development and experimental testing for undergraduate students at the PI’s home institution; 4) Regular presentations given by undergraduate and graduate students during weekly seminars; 5) New graduate-level course curriculum development in the area of control system theory; 6) The development of new versatile and computationally inexpensive control design techniques, which could facilitate widespread implementation of SJAs in small UAV applications, for which there has been a recent surge of interest in various industries; 7) The publication of a patent, which is based on the inexpensively implementable (single-feedback-loop) SJA-based control methods developed in this research.

    William Mackunis
    Seemless SJA-based Aircraft
  • The SJA "virtual" surface deflection angle versus SJA voltage input, showing the nonlinearity and the effect on control resulting from off-nominal SJA parameter values.
    William MacKunis
    Public Domain
    William Mackunis
    Nonlinear, Uncertain SJA Model
  • The trajectory tracking performance of a UAV using a new SJA-based control method. The plots show the tracking errors in the UAV's roll, pitch, and yaw angles for 20 simulations testing up to 35% SJA parameter uncertainty. These results were achieved using six arrays of SJA as an example.
    William MacKunis
    Public Domain
    William Mackunis
    SJA-based UAV Tracking Control
